entry.title: Contrail Announces FA50 for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. At the #FSExpoFriday event during FlightSimExpo 2025, Contrail founder Lars Pinkenburg announced that the team is currently developing the FA50 for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024. This aircraft will be the first one developed in-house by Contrail. The Dassault Falcon 50, known for its tri-engine design, has been utilised by both private and military operators globally. This aircraft is certified to reach altitudes of up to 49,000 feet and is capable of flying both transcontinental and transoceanic routes. The addon will be equipped with fully customised avionics systems, including the GNSXLS Flight Management System, the Apollo MX20 MFD, the Collins Electronic Flight Information System suite, and a dedicated custom autopilot. Currently, the aircraft is set to feature 18 different liveries. While the price has not yet been determined, it is expected to be released in 2025. We will keep you updated as soon as the team shares new information. â For the latest flight simulation news, remember to stay tuned on Threshold! â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon!

entry.title: WinWing Announces New Products at the FSExpo 2025
entry.summary: Sim: OTHER. WinWing has announced a variety of new products at the #FSExpoFriday event during FlightSimExpo 2025, following their announcements at FSWeekend 2025. This latest release includes flight simulation hardware designed for both the commercial and combat sectors. The team began by announcing a variety of new products for the commercial sector. First, they introduced the ATC 32, ACP 32, and RMP 32. The prices for the ATC 32 and RMP 32 are set at $77.50 each, while the ACP 32 is priced at $133.85. Next, they unveiled the AGP 32, which is a landing gear and autobrake panel, also priced at $133.85. They also released the ECAM 32, an ECAM panel, priced at $77.50.Â Following that was the NWS L 32, a left-sided Airbus tiller, priced at $82.30. Finally, they introduced the N32 rudder pedals, which are priced at $328.69. Additionally, there will be two Force Feedback (FFB) variants of these rudder pedals, designated as EB140 32 and EB400 32, available for $499.95 and $599.95, respectively. The next announcement highlighted new products in the combat sector. Two new rudder pedals have been introduced: the EB140 N and the EB400 N. These are combat variants of the original EB140 32 and EB400 32 models, priced at $499.95 and $599.95, respectively. The previously announced FFB Boeing Yoke was also on display; however, the price has not yet been determined. Lastly, the Met 29 Grips were showcased. The Joystick Grip R Met 29 is priced at $222.45, while the Throttle Grip R Met 29 is priced at $141.06. entry.title: iniBuilds Updates A350 Airliner for MSFS 2020/2024 with ULR Variant, Teases A340
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. iniBuilds has released version 1.1.0 of its A350 Airliner for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024, bringing a raft of improvements and additions, including the long-awaited A350 ULR variant. The A350 ULR, or Ultra Long Range, features an increased maximum takeoff weight and fuel capacity, with a range of up to 9,700 nautical miles. Designed for non-stop, ultra-long-haul flights, it supports operations lasting over 19 hours, with Singapore Airlines operating the type exclusively, in a two-class, premium-heavy configuration. iniBuilds has adapted this layout for their ULR variant in MSFS 2024, bringing a reworked cabin and compatibility with FS24âs career mode, including interactive boarding procedures. Further additions include the integration of functional emergency evacuation slides and the PDOS (Power Door Opening System) for opening the engine cowlings. Performance has seen additional improvements, with reduced CPU load and a streamlined WASM structure. Furthermore, iniBuilds has overhauled the ECAM, refined the fly-by-wire system, and introduced several new FMS features, including Conditional Descent Advisory and Estimated Time to Target. The update also introduces support for iniBuilds' new modular cabin packs, a separately sold line of swappable, airline-specific interiors, providing realistic cabin layouts from carriers like Air France, Virgin Atlantic and Lufthansa. Artwork updates include refined nose cone shading, reworked cockpit sidesticks, adjusted camera positions, and cockpit storm lighting. iniBuilds has also integrated event-driven scenarios and confirmed upcoming support for a 3D HUD with dynamic projection and crosswind adaptation. Despite popular demand, 8x time compression remains unsupported, due to instability in the autopilot logic at high speeds. iniBuilds also affirmed their confidence in the aircraftâs flight model, citing validation through full-motion simulators, while noting user experience may vary depending on hardware. The developer recommends users apply a 1:1 axis curve for the most accurate control feel.Â â iniBuilds closed their post with a single teaser image of what appears to be an Airbus A340-300, possibly hinting at their next big project. As the A350 Airliner enters a more mature development phase, iniBuilds plans to space out future updates, while continuing work on feature enhancements and long-term refinements. â You can find the entry.title: Laminar Research Showcases X-Plane 12.3 Update at the FSExpo 2025
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. Laminar has during during #FSExpoFriday 2025 given an update on the future of X-Plane 12, with performance improvements, art upgrades, and major simulation system enhancements all in active development. The team confirmed that version 12.2.1 will enter public beta next Friday, while the highly anticipated 12.3.0 release will begin private beta testing the same day. â The presentation began with a recap of version 12.2, which is now publicly available. Key fixes and visual improvements include updated ground textures, revised lighting and atmospheric rendering, new aircraft braking effects, and a resolution to the long-standing dark cockpit issue, significantly improving visibility across default aircraft. Laminar also previewed upcoming additions to the X-Plane Gateway, with new community-driven assets currently in development. These include various fire trucks, police cars, construction vehicles, enhanced ramp lighting, and improved ground markings. Much of this work is being led by newly joined scenery artist Justin, also known as Mr. X, and the team highlighted the ability to customise ramps with new compass roses, labels, and colours. The upcoming 12.3.0 version will introduce a foundational shift in how X-Plane uses CPU resources. Laminar has confirmed that multi-core rendering is now in development, with a new job system already built to handle AI traffic, texture paging, and network synchronisation. Internal testing has demonstrated performance gains of up to 30% at graphically intensive airports, such as Frankfurt. Additional optimisation targets GPU and VRAM usage. Laminar is currently refining cloud rendering and night lighting processes, which should result in greater efficiency and reduced GPU workload, particularly beneficial for users running in 4K. Laminar is adopting new virtual memory techniques, to speed up texture loading and safely offload unused graphical assets. The default Airbus A330 is set for a major update, with reworked metallic surfaces, improved textures, detailed weathering and glare shield fixes. Furthermore, brake fire simulations, refined lighting and cabin ambience, dynamic passenger lighting, and altitude-aware illumination modes were also shown off. A major technical addition is a fully GPU-bound weather radar, integrated by default on the default Boeing 737-800, A330-300, MD-82, Cirrus Visionjet, Baron B58 and Citation X. The default weather radar includes manual tilt, ground clutter filtering, sector scanning, and predictive wind shear alerts. An API has been made available for third-party developers to integrate the feature into their products. â The G1000 avionics suite has also been upgraded, now featuring synthetic vision, rendered entirely on the GPU. This allows terrain, obstacle, and traffic overlays, including support for online networks like VATSIM and IVAO, without adding CPU overhead or impacting performance. Beyond the simulator core, Laminar reaffirmed progress on its new X-Plane Store. The backend now supports account-based logins and is integrating modern payment systems. â More details are expected as development on the 12.3.0 update continues. â For all the latest updates, be sure to follow Threshold! â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon! â

entry.title: Aerosoft and ToLiss Reveal Partnership for A340-600 in Microsoft Flight Simulator
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Aerosoft and ToLiss have announced a new partnership at this year's FlightSimExpo, confirming development of an Airbus A340-600 for MSFS. The upcoming release will mark ToLissâ first entry into the MSFS platform, having already built a reputation for high-fidelity Airbus aircraft in X-Plane. In a statement published on Facebook, ToLiss said the aircraft will feature their proprietary systems suite adapted from X-Plane. It will also include a custom-built flight model, designed specifically for MSFS. The aircraft is being jointly developed, with Aerosoft handling modelling and visual assets, and ToLiss the flight and systems modelling. While no release timeline has been shared, a recently published video on the Aerosoft Flight YouTube channel showcases the A340 handling three different technical scenarios, including an engine failure after takeoff, and sections of an RNAV approach.Â A standout feature is a seemingly working taxi camera, rarely seen in MSFS due to simulator limitations. ToLiss has long been recognised in the X-Plane community for its attention to detail and system accuracy, notably in the A319, A321, A340 and A330neo series. Their upcoming A340-600 for MSFS aims to bring the same level of depth to a new audience. â Further details on the project, including pricing and release platforms, are expected as development continues. â Be sure to follow Threshold for the latest updates! â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon! â

entry.title: Got Friends Announces the imminent Release of the AS 33 Me Motor Glider for Microsoft Flight Simulator, with Discus 2c also receiving Upgrades.
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Got Friends is about to release their AS 33 Me Motor glider for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024. It will include both 15-meter and 18-meter variants and has been developed in collaboration with three-time World Gliding Champion, Stefan Langer. According to Got Friends, the avionics suite is highly advanced and will support task-based navigation, thermal tracking, customizable instrument layouts, and more. The aircraft is designed to provide a flexible experience for both experienced and casual players, allowing for a reduction in complexity as needed. The AS 33 Me will also include a new LXNav gliding computer and a variety of liveries. â Got Friends states that this will be their most advanced aircraft to date. It is set to release on July 1st for both Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024 at a price of $19.99. entry.title: Drzewiecki Design Releases Western Sydney International Airport for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Drzewiecki Design has recently released its rendition of Western Sydney International Airport (YSWS) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024. This airport is situated approximately 38 miles from the center of Sydney and is currently under construction, with a projected completion date at the end of 2026. Once finished, it will serve as a supplement to the existing Sydney Kingsford Smith Airport (YSSY). Construction of the new Western Sydney International Airport began in 2018 and is expected to be completed by late 2026. This airport will be notable for using a remote and virtual control tower rather than the traditional air traffic control tower, making it the first airport in Australia to feature this technology. The new airport is being built to supplement the existing Sydney Kingsford Smith Airport (YSSY), which has limited space for expansion. As of now, airlines including Qantas, Jetstar, and Singapore Airlines have announced plans to operate flights to the new airport. The new scenery includes an up-to-date and high-quality model of the airport, advanced night lighting, custom jetways, and many additional features. The newly released Western Sydney International Airport is now available from SimMarket for approximately $23.44. â For the latest flight simulation news, remember to stay tuned on Threshold! â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon!

entry.title: Aerosoft updates CRJ for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Aerosoft has released version 2.1.10 of its CRJ series for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024, introducing a host of system fixes, art adjustments, and enhancements. The update applies across all CRJ variants, and introduces refinements to both the flight and engine models, aiming to improve handling and realism. In addition to aerodynamic adjustments, the update enhances cockpit visuals, with changes to elements like seat indicators, gear levers, and air outlets. Numerous bugs have been resolved, such as errors with waypoint logic, autopilot disengagement behaviour in MSFS 2024, and missing or misrepresented indicators within the MCDU. The release also expands compatibility with SimBrief, including support for alternate flight plan imports, and reworks the autopilot logic, for greater stability and accuracy. Version 2.1.10 also includes improvements to various systems, such as time and distance calculations, corrections to flex temperature performance values, and updated DME arc handling. Visual bugs, like the EICAS outline, weather radar behaviour, and various display elements, have also been addressed. Quality-of-life additions include VR camera enhancements, smoother cockpit transitions, GSX ground power unit support, and fixes for flight planning inconsistencies and sound triggers, such as cabin chimes and pushback audio cues. entry.title: A2A Simulations Releases Piper Aerostar 600 for MSFS 2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. A2A Simulations has released their Accu-Sim Aerostar 600 for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024 in Early Access. It's the company's first fully native aircraft for the new platform, taking full advantage of its features, performance enhancements, and visual capabilities. It enters early access in a late beta stage, with most of its systems and features already in place, only requiring a bit of further polishing as they move toward the full release.Â The Aerostar 600 was designed and built by Ted Smith Aircraft Company in the late 1960s, with speed, sleekness, and power in mind. It was the fastest twin-piston general aviation aircraft during its heyday. Powered by two Lycoming IO-540-K engines, each producing 290 horsepower, it can cruise at 408 km/h, with a service ceiling of 25,000ft and 1,500 nautical miles of range on a single tank. Like their Comanche 250, it is built on their proprietary Accu-Sim 2.0 technology, bringing an advanced aerodynamic system that faithfully represents how the airplane's surfaces interact with the air, along with realistic simulation of wear and tear on the airframe and engine, an in-depth electrical simulation, and much more. The complete feature list follows below: â¢ Optimized Performance: Fully Native MSFS2024 model with all the LOD and performance features that comes with a native model. Fluid in-sim performance comparable to default MSFS2024 aircraft. â â¢ Accu-Sim 2.0 Aerodynamics: Physics-based external aerodynamics engine for realistic flight dynamics, validated against real-world Aerostar performance. â â¢ Per-Cylinder Engine Simulation: Complete physics-based model of twin Lycoming IO-540-G1B5 engines, simulating fuel injection, ignition, and wear. â â¢ Dynamic Ground Physics: True weight-on-wheels simulation, tire side-loading, and surface-specific responses (e.g., pavement, grass). â â¢ Sophisticated Vibration Physics: Realistic ground roll and engine vibration effects, unique to the Aerostarâs twin-engine configuration. â â¢ Authentic Fuel System: Simulates fuel lines, crossfeed, boost pumps, and contamination risks, with 174.5 gallons usable capacity. â â¢ Custom Oil System: Dynamic viscosity and contaminants that degrade oil, affecting engine performance. â â¢ Advanced Starter Simulation: Physically turns engines through compression cycles, with realistic starting challenges. â â¢ Physics-Driven Sound Environment: Over 1,000 dynamic sound effects, including engine rumble, hydraulic pumps, and cockpit interactions. â â¢ Detailed Modeling: High-fidelity external and internal textures with wear effects, dynamic registration decals, and animations. â â¢ Custom Avionics Stack: Collins Microline avionics with AMR-350 audio panel, VHF-251 COM radios, VIR-351 nav receivers, IND-450 DME, ADF-650 and TDR-950 transponder â â¢ GPS Integration: Supports MSFS default/Working Title GNS 430W/530W, freeware KLN-90B, PMS GTN 750, and TDS GTN 750Xi (if installed). â â¢ Century NSD-360A HSI: Custom needle-smoothing physics for realistic navigation. â â¢ Century IV Autopilot: Advanced two-axis autopilot simulation. â¢ Simulation of JPI EDM 790 and EDM 760 digital engine monitors, with authentic displays and leaning procedures. Both Rich of Peak and Lean of Peak modes are available. â â¢ Native MSFS2024 Pilotâs 2D/3D Tablet: Intuitive interface for fuel, payload, maintenance, and engine analysis, with environmental data display and more. â â¢ Interactive Walkaround: Inspect moving parts (e.g., control surfaces, gear) with failure and wear simulation. â â¢ Persistent Aircraft: Customizable wear and failure rates, adjustable via tablet, with persistence by livery. â â¢ Graphical Engine Analyzer: Detailed insight into engine operation, including cylinder pressures and temperatures. â â¢ Real-Time Load Manager: Dynamic weight and balance with graphical CG indicator. It's available on their website for $49.99. If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon! â

entry.title: Just Flight Publishes F70/F100 Development Update for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Just Flight has recently published a new development update on their upcoming Fokker 70/100 for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024, showcasing their advancements on what allegedly pushes the boundaries of what their products can deliver. The developers take us on a test flight from Salzburg to Brussels using the latest beta version of their Fokker 100 Professional. They highlight that it is still very much a work in progress, with bugs and unfinished elements to be expected (and pointed out along the way). They start by showcasing the flight deck with its sweet mixture of CRT displays and analogue gauges from the beginning of the âglass cockpitâ era. The texturing was made using reference imagery of the real aircraft, and it also includes customizable elements such as different taxi light configurations and multiple panel and instrument configurations across the F70 and 100. â The externals have also been based on real imagery, with hand-placed rivets, screws, and panels.Â â Just Flight has also paid special attention to the cabin, bringing a meticulous craft of the Fokker 100âs different passenger cabin configurations, with internal and external cargo and passenger door options, changing per livery configuration. The work on the cabin is mostly complete, with the only remaining things being fine-tuning the lighting and integrating specific cabin-to-cockpit interactions. â They have been focusing a lot on performance optimization, achieving FPS figures within 5% of the default 747 and 787 in MSFS 2020 with their latest F100 beta build. Just Flight reinforces that FPS figures will vary from machine to machine, scenery to scenery, and so on. They will encourage content creators to show performance figures once they are given access to the product for their reviews. The interactive checklists were included in full, housing over 300 items, 250 of which you are supposed to check before take-off, albeit most of them are only checked during the first flight of the day after a cold and dark startup. From all the tests and stuff, they have yet to complete the annunciator test, which involves a very specific, ordered illumination of all the cockpit annunciators. They captured a slow-motion video of this test from a real Fokker, allowing them to replicate it with maximum accuracy. Their FMS (Flight Management System) is custom-coded from scratch, including features such as IRS alignment (real-time and fast align), manual IRS alignment adjustment, manual flight plan entry, automatic and manual navaid tuning, navigation and performance monitoring, custom waypoint creation, and vertical navigation. They will dive deeper into the FMS in their upcoming marketing content and operations manual. The FMS on both the F70 and F100 is said to be the most complex system they have developed so far, as itâs the heart of the aircraft, interacting with the autopilot, flight model, EFIS displays, and other systems. This complexity takes time to develop and has been the most time-consuming part so far, but they consider it feature-complete as of now.Â Based on recent testing, Just Flight claims their F70/F100 add-on is within 95% of real-world data, sometimes even reaching 100% accuracy in certain phases of the climb profile. The accuracy will continue to improve as the company further develops the product. Their Fokker 100 is already able to perform a successful autoland, although they have to be âextra vigilantâ due to the beta nature of their aircraft.Â There is no pricing or release date information yet, but Just Flight plans to share more information soon. They are very proud of how far they have come with their most ambitious project yet in terms of sheer complexity. entry.title: Just Flight Publishes A300B4 Professional Development Update for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Just Flight recently published a new development update on their upcoming Airbus A300B4 Professional for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024. The update showcases the artwork on the now fully complete flight deck based on a real airframe (F-WUAB). The flight deck will be highly configurable, with multiple possible configurations toggleable via EFB or variant-dependent. While they are currently focusing on recreating the A300B4-203 variant fitted with an INS, they will also offer the option to use the UNS-1 FMS and TCAS VSI. A full list of all the possible configurations will be shared prior to the release. The passenger cabin is nearing completion, with over 200 seats and an interior design that screams 1980s. Itâs said to perfectly capture the era, except for the cigarette smoke (which they jokingly considered adding to the feature request list). A dedicated feature update on their cabin progress is coming soon. Furthermore, Just Flight can finally share external shots of the A300 for the first time in the new platform (as it was initially intended for P3D). Upon platform transition, they decided to start nearly from scratch to meet MSFSâs visual standards. â The work on the exterior modeling is said to be 95% complete, and the only things remaining are the second engine variant and the wing flex. Every rivet, screw, fastener, panel line, weathered surface, and text decal was carefully hand placed on the exterior, ensuring maximum accuracy. Itâs a massive undertaking for an airplane this big. Their development team has recently revisited the real aircraft to gather more high-resolution images, filling specific gaps in their photograph collection and allowing them to detect certain discrepancies in previously textured areas, which have since been corrected. Systems-wise, they have now integrated the systems code into their MSFS version of the aircraft, meaning it is now âaliveâ in the simulator, and their internal testing team can start evaluating it. The systems integration happened later in the development stage because most was already complete due to their original P3D development effort, meaning their first MSFS build already features a highly advanced systems suite. â The aircraftâs core systems are said to be fully custom-coded, aiming to achieve maximum fidelity. They exemplify the depth by mentioning how the A300 has 10 fuel pumps â two in each fuel tank âand the fuel pressure supplied by each pump is slightly different, varying every time you load into the aircraft, replicating what youâd see in the real aircraft. â Systems-wise, most of what is still being worked on is navigation-related, such as the autopilot and the INS. Work is progressing well, though, and they will share more information on those soon in future development updates. â There is still no release date or pricing information, but Threshold will keep you informed as development progresses.
